detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Course Description: Aristotle stands beside Plato as one of the dominant figures of ancient Greek philosophy and its legacy. His philosophical system offers new answers to problems of continuity through change; causation and the fundamental principles of the natural world; the nature of living beings; the soul, perceiving and thinking; and the goal of human life. In this course, we will approach Aristotle as a systematic thinker studying nature and human nature.
This is a reading-intensive lecture course: focus will be on reading and understanding primary texts from the corpus of Aristotles works, in English translation. Attendance at lectures is expected. There will be a fair amount of reading, some of it dense. Students should read the assigned chapters before class and bring texts to class: quizzes and the literature final exam will test your knowledge of the course readings.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Course Description: Introduction to Medieval Philosophy, using Augustine's seminalConfessions as a starting-point and tracing its influence down the centuries up to Modern Philosophy.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Course Description: Overview of political thought in the 1800s, focusing on seminal writings of Hegel, and reactions and responses in JS Mill, Marx, and Nietzsche.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Law and legality are such pervasive aspects of our social reality that it can be difficult to bring them into proper focus. Philosophy is a lens through which to achieve such focus. We shall tackle a range of important law-related topics that philosophy illuminates. These include: the nature of law and legal authority; the relationship between law and morality; crime and punishment; legal evidence and proof; causation and legal responsibility; and privacy.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Course Description: Overview of contemporary metaphysics, focusing on questions about the existence of immaterialminds, free will, time, and the question ofwhat it means to have objective existence at all.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Course Description: Overview of the main arguments for and against the existence of God; the question of what constitutes responsible belief; and the changingconcept of religion. Note: this course is offered in parallel classroom and online sections.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
This is a Synchronous Online course: learning activities that happen at the same time for the instructor and the learners, facilitating real-time interaction between them.

Course delivery mode: Hybrid = Lectures synchronous online + Exams (midterm and final) in person

PHIL371.002 is cross-listed with ASIA371.021. Please register in ASIA371.021.

ASIA371.021 is a synchronous online course.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Course Description: Philosophy and Literature" addresses philosophical issues in works of literature or arising from theories of literary interpretation. Topics include issues relating to relativism, the nature of morality, free will, personal identity, the nature of the emotions. This course in particular will be about the question what the interpretation of texts and the methods associated with interpretation (hermeneutics) can teach us about more general philosophical questions such as metaphysics, scientific method, moral responsibility, and personal identity.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
This seminar course is open only to Philosophy Honours students.Non-PHIL HON students enrolled in this course section will be removed.
ATTENTION Philosophy Honours Students: This honours seminar course is one of the requirements to complete your philosophy honours degree. Please ensure that you do not register in any other classes during your assigned honours seminar timeslot. If you have any concerns or encounter registration issues, please reach out to phil.undergrad@ubc.ca.

uiLabels.WDRES.FACETEDSEARCH.SymanSyntax:
Boolean logic can be expressed using AND, OR, NOT, and (). 
Exact phrases can be surrounded by double quotation marks. 
Example: ("software engineer" OR computer science) AND ~manager~.
